conclusion: Identify the Given Data: Temperature at state A: \( T_A = -73^{\circ}C = 200 \, K \) (using the conversion \( T(K) = T(^{\circ}C) + 273 \)), Pressure at state A: \( p_A = 3 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \), Volume at state A: \( V_A = 1 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \), Pressure at state C: \( p_C = 1 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \), Volume at state C: \( V_C = 3 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \)
Use the Ideal Gas Law: The ideal gas law is given by: \( PV = nRT \). For states A and C, we have: \( p_A V_A = nR T_A \) and \( p_C V_C = nR T_C \)

premise: Use the Ideal Gas Law: The ideal gas law is given by: \( PV = nRT \). For states A and C, we have: \( p_A V_A = nR T_A \) and \( p_C V_C = nR T_C \)
conclusion: Relate Temperatures Using the Ideal Gas Law: \( \frac{p_A V_A}{T_A} = \frac{p_C V_C}{T_C} \)

premise: Relate Temperatures Using the Ideal Gas Law: \( \frac{p_A V_A}{T_A} = \frac{p_C V_C}{T_C} \)
conclusion: Calculate the Temperature at State C: Substituting the given values into the equation: \( \frac{3 \times 10^5 \times 1 \times 10^{-3}}{200} = \frac{1 \times 10^5 \times 3 \times 10^{-3}}{T_C} \)
